bestBHT.bht: The verse refers to the crucifixion of Jesus. The details of his crucifixion, including the mocking and the resurrection on the third day, often go unnoticed. The religious leaders at the time could not comprehend that Jesus' words about rising again were meant to be taken literally, going against their beliefs of a Messiah establishing an earthly kingdom. (50 words)

Henry Alford: and (but in Matthew only) His crucifixion. See the note on the more detailed account in Mark.
Archibald T. Robertson: And to crucify (κα σταυρωσα). The very word now. The details fall on deaf ears, even the point of the resurrection on the third day.
John Gill: To mock him, as they did, by putting on him a scarlet robe, platting a crown of thorns, and placing it on his head, and a reed in his hand; and then bowed the knee to him, and cried, hail, king of the Jews!" (30 words)

The words were plain, the grammatical sense of them was easy, but they could not imagine that they were to be taken literally; which was such a glaring contradiction to their received and rooted principles of the temporal kingdom of the Messiah." (46 words)
What he said about rising again, which seemed to have put them afresh in mind, and to excite their hopes of this external felicity." (26 words)

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse refers to the crucifixion of Jesus. The details of his crucifixion, including the mocking and the resurrection on the third day, often go unnoticed. The religious leaders at the time could not comprehend that Jesus' words about rising again were meant to be taken literally, going against their beliefs of a Messiah establishing an earthly kingdom. Jesus' crucifixion, specifically mentioned in Matthew, often goes overlooked. The details, like the mocking and the resurrection on the third day, seem to fall on deaf ears. The religious leaders struggled with the concept of Jesus rising again, as it challenged their deeply ingrained beliefs about an earthly kingdom for the Messiah. (50 words)

The details of Jesus' crucifixion often go unnoticed, even though they are specifically mentioned in Matthew. The religious leaders at the time couldn't comprehend that Jesus' words about rising again were meant to be taken literally. This concept contradicted their deeply rooted beliefs about the Messiah establishing a temporal kingdom. (47 words)

The crucifixion of Jesus, a significant event only mentioned in Matthew, tends to be overlooked. The specific details surrounding His crucifixion, such as the mockery He endured and His resurrection on the third day, often go unnoticed or fail to resonate. The religious leaders of the time struggled to comprehend the literal meaning behind Jesus' words about His resurrection, as it contradicted their firmly established beliefs about an earthly kingdom for the Messiah. (66 words)

The crucifixion of Jesus, mentioned exclusively in Matthew, is a significant event that often gets overlooked. The specific details are disregarded, including the mockery He endured and His resurrection on the third day. The religious leaders of the time struggled to comprehend the literal meaning behind Jesus' words about His resurrection, as it contradicted their firmly established beliefs about an earthly kingdom for the Messiah.
